summary: This is a Federal Bureau of Prisons Program Statement (P5324.08) establishing the Suicide Prevention Program. It outlines detailed procedures for identifying, assessing, and managing potentially suicidal inmates, including training requirements, risk assessments, intervention protocols, and suicide watch procedures. The document is a general policy manual, not specific to any individual case. This document is the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy statement P5324.08, titled 'Suicide Prevention Program,' dated April 5, 2007. It outlines detailed procedures for identifying, managing, and preventing inmate suicides, including the use of staff and inmate observers, watch termination protocols, transfer procedures, and post-suicide analysis. It is signed by the BOP Director.

keyFacts: This is a standard Bureau of Prisons policy document (P5324.08) dated April 5, 2007, establishing procedures for suicide prevention in federal prisons.
The policy mandates specific training, including three mock suicide emergencies per year (one per shift), with one required in the Special Housing Unit (SHU).
It details procedures for identifying at-risk inmates, conducting Suicide Risk Assessments, and placing inmates on suicide watch in designated rooms.
The document explicitly states that all possible evidence and documentation must be preserved in the event of a suicide to support subsequent investigators.
The policy applies to all Bureau institutions, Medical Referral Centers, Residential Reentry Centers, and privately-managed contract prisons.
This is the official BOP Suicide Prevention Program policy (P5324.08) effective April 5, 2007, establishing national protocols for inmate suicide watch.
The policy details the use of both staff and inmate observers (companions) for suicide watches, with inmate observers requiring specific Warden authorization and training.
It mandates that an inmate determined to be 'imminently suicidal' cannot be transferred except to a medical center on an emergency basis.
The policy requires a detailed psychological reconstruction and after-action review following any inmate suicide, with reports sent to central BOP offices.
The document is signed by Harley G. Lappin, who was the Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons at the time.
